prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Science Goal HD172555
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
What we learn in step 1 (cycle-3):
Dust (continuum): Both HD172555 and Eta Tel have been imaged by our team (Smith et al. 2009, 2012) and so we have a good idea of the radial location of the mid-IR emission and a crude understanding of its sub-mm flux. Our primary objective is to obtain a sub-mm flux. This will allow future higher resolution imaging to be planned, but will also provide information on the spectral slope. We will model the spectral slope to get constraints on the size distribution of the dust. For example, a steep slope would be indicative of an overabundance of small dust indicating a high level of collisional activity, whereas a shallow slope could be indicative of a lack of small dust due to its loss by interaction with gas. We will also obtain crude information on the size of the mm emission. This could differ from that seen in the mid-IR, because mm-wavelengths probe mm-sized grains that trace the planetesimals and mid-IR-wavelengths probe micron-sized grains that can be pushed to larger distances by radiation pressure or smaller distances by gas drag. The resolution is set to compare the mm-size with that seen in the mid-IR and so to determine the effects of gas and radiation pressure on small dust in the system which can be interpreted in the context of the level of stirring in the disk (e.g., Thebault & Wu 2008).
Gas (lines): Gas has been already been detected in HD172555 (OI and SiO) and in Eta Tel (CII). The production of carbon and oxygen arises naturally from the photodissociation of CO. This seems to be the case in Beta Pic, for which ALMA detected CO which displayed a morphology showing it is produced in the break-up of icy planetesimals (Dent et al. 2014). It is hard to guarantee detection of CO in any debris disk, however those with previous detections are (like our sample) all <30Myr A stars (Matra et al. 2015), and the previous photodissociation products increase our chances of such a detection. SiO has already been detected in HD 172555 (Johnson et al. 2012) and a follow up is needed with ALMA resolution. Successful detection of CO or SiO in these systems would give invaluable information, since we the spectral resolution means that we could determine the radial location of the gas and so break degeneracies with the quantity of gas present. This would also allow us to tell if this is associated with the giant impact or the (possibly) steady state processes on-going at larger radii. We have already successfully used gas kinematical information to determine the giant impact location in Beta Pic, demonstrating how this helps to disentangle projection effects caused by a disc's nearly edge-on orientation (as is the case for both of our sample).
What we learn in step 2: The second step would be proposed in cycle-4. It is hard to predict the exact outcome. However, with an accurate sub-mm flux, and information on the radial location of the emission, as well as on the gas content of the disk and its radial location, we could begin to address the science questions mentioned above. That is, we could search for the asymmetries and narrow radial structures that are the signatures of different planet formation processes.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We have chosen this particular setup to be able to observe both the CO J=3-2 and SiO J=8-7 lines.

We go for a low 0.59'' resolution (376m baseline) to evaluate accurately the total flux from the system. We know our sources extensions thanks to resolved images in mid-IR which ensures that the largest angular scale is smaller than 0.7''.

We propose to image HD172555 using 3 hours and Eta Tel using 1 hour of band 7 (850 microns) at 0.59'' resolution. Band 7 is the most sensitive for our observations and emission lines of CO and SiO are present. Our rms requirements are based on the continuum observations. We used the OST to simulate the ALMA observations from our SED extrapolation modelling (shown in the proposal). We expect a total flux of 0.42mJy for HD172555 (with a star flux of 85microJy) and 0.4mJy for Eta Tel (with a star flux of 50microJy) in band 7. For HD172555 we assumed that the sub-mm disk is located between 6-9AU and for Eta Tel between 22-26AU. We tried the worst case where beta=2 for the SED and would still have a detection so that the detection is guaranteed.
Thanks to ALMA sensitivity, CO is observed around a growing number of debris disks (HD21997, 49 Ceti, beta Pic) suggesting that it is a product of debris disks. Gas has been observed in HD172555 and Eta Tel by Herschel, and the likely explanation for its origin is that it should be produced by photodissociation of CO so that the latter should be present at some level. SiO has already been observed in HD172555 and should be seen by ALMA. These two gas observations are at no extra cost as both emission lines are within our waveband. If detected this would confirm that the observed atomic species come from CO photodissociation and it would give unprecedented details on the location of planetary formation thanks to the kinematic information that can be extracted from gas observations. We would model any gas detections using the framework set up in Matra et al. (2015), which was necessary to consider the optically thin debris environments where hydrogen may not be present. This means that the standard assumptions of gas in LTE with a primordial composition cannot be used.

We have chosen a 976kHz resolution to be able to have radial information from the lines which is very important for our science case (see proposal). The first baseband is set for both CO 3-2 and SiO 8-7 and the rest are TDM for continuum.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Science Goal eta Tel

What we learn in step 1 (cycle-3):
Dust (continuum): Both HD172555 and Eta Tel have been imaged by our team (Smith et al. 2009, 2012) and so we have a good idea of the radial location of the mid-IR emission and a crude understanding of its sub-mm flux. That is, we could search for the asymmetries and narrow radial structures that are the signatures of different planet formation processes.

We propose to image HD172555 using 3 hours and Eta Tel using 1 hour of band 7 (850 microns) at 0.59'' resolution. prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: A handful of debris disks are known to represent dust created in the final stages of terrestrial planet formation. Here we propose to image the two nearest and brightest examples of terrestrial planet formation in action, i.e., the ~20Myr A stars HD172555 and Eta Tel. As well as debris in the terrestrial planet region with further evidence for giant impacts, both have debris at a larger radius previously resolved in the mid-IR as well as gas at an unknown location. These systems provide a unique opportunity to witness planet formation processes at play, and to place the formation of terrestrial planets within the context of what is going on at this epoch throughout the system. We will use low resolution (0.59'') to determine the total band 7 flux and resolve the radii of the outer debris. This will already place constraints on the level of dynamical activity and the underlying physics (e.g., presence of gas), as well as providing information needed for high resolution follow-up for further signatures of planet formation. We will also observe CO J=3-2 and SiO J=8-7 to determine if the gas is associated with the giant impact, and use its kinematics to constrain the disk structure.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system
